sen.j: 植松 雅孝（うえまつ まさたか、貞享4年8月26日 (旧暦)（1687年10月2日） - 享保15年9月24日 (旧暦)（1730年11月4日））は、江戸時代中期の公卿。
sen.e: Masataka UEMATSU (October 2, 1687-November 4, 1730) was a Court noble of the middle of the Edo period.
Masataka UEMATSU (October 2, 1687-November 4, 1730) was a Court noble during the middle of the Edo period.
Masataka UEMATSU (October 2, 1687 - November 4, 1730) was a Kugyo (top court official) during the mid Edo period.
sen.cmt: Kugyo (top court official) としました。

sen.j: 主に東山天皇（113代）・中御門天皇（114代）の二代にわたり朝廷に仕え、官位は正三位宮内卿まで昇った。
sen.e: He attended at the Imperial court to serve mainly two consecutive emperors, Emperor Higashiyama (113rd) and Emperor Nakamikado (114th), and moved up in official rank to Shosanmi Kunaikyo (Senior Third Rank, Minister of the Sovereign's Household).

He attended the Imperial court to serve mainly two consecutive emperors, Emperor Higashiyama (113rd) and Emperor Nakamikado (114th), and moved up in official rank to Shosanmi Kunaikyo (Senior Third Rank, Minister of the Sovereign's Household).

He attended the Imperial Court to serve mainly two consecutive emperors, Emperor Higashiyama (113th) and Emperor Nakamikado (114th), and moved up in official rank to Shosanmi Kunaikyo (Senior Third Rank, Minister of the Sovereign's Household).
His father was Masanaga UEMATSU, who was Sangi (councillor).
His father was Masanaga UEMATSU, who was Sangi (councillor).
His father was Masanaga UEMATSU, who was Sangi (councilor).
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 子に植松幸雅（左近衛中将）。
sen.e: He had a son, Yoshimasa UEMATSU, who was Sakone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards).
He had a son, Yoshimasa UEMATSU, who was Sakone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards).
He had a son, Yoshimasa UEMATSU, who was Sakone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards).

sen.j: 養子に植松賞雅（権中納言）。
sen.e: He had an adopted son, Takamasa UEMATSU, who was Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state)
He had an adopted son, Takamasa UEMATSU, who was Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state)
He had an adopted son, Takamasa UEMATSU, who was Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state)

sen.j: はじめ雅康と名乗った。
sen.e: His initial name was Masayasu.
His initial name was Masayasu.
His initial name was Masayasu.
Conferred a peerage in 1691.
Conferred peerage in 1691.
He was conferred peerage in 1691.
Genpuku (celebrated his coming of age) in 1700.
Genpuku (celebrated his coming of age) in 1700.
He celebrated his coming-of-age ceremony in 1700.
sen.cmt: 元服 の表現を英語にしました。

sen.j: 以降、右近衛少将や左近衛中将を経て、享保4年（1719年）に従三位となり公卿に列する。
sen.e: Thereafter, he held Ukone no shosho (Minor Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Sakone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards), and was subsequently conferred to the Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1719 and ranked as a Court noble.

Thereafter, he held Ukone no shosho (Minor Captain of the Right Division of the Inner Palace Guards) and Sakone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards), and was subsequently conferred Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1719 and ranked as a Court noble.

Thereafter, he held Ukone no shosho (Minor Captain of the Right Division of the Inner Palace Guards) and Sakone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards), and was subsequently conferred Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in 1719 and ranked as one of the Kugyo.
sen.cmt: one of the Kugyo とし、他の記事と合わせました。

sen.j: 享保11年（1726年）に雅孝と改名した。
sen.e: Changed his name to Masataka in 1726.
Changed his name to Masataka in 1726.
He changed his name to Masataka in 1726.

sen.j: 享保13年（1728年）宮内卿となり、御所の庶務を司ったが、まもなく病に罹いった。
sen.e: He was appointed to Kunaikyo (Minister of the Sovereign's Household) and administered general affairs of the imperial palace, but soon started suffering illness.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He was appointed to Kunaikyo (Minister of the Sovereign's Household) and administered general affairs of the imperial palace, but soon started suffering from illness.
He was appointed to Kunaikyo (Minister of the Sovereign's Household) in 1728 and administered general affairs of the Imperial Palace, but soon started suffering from illness.

sen.j: 享保15年（1730年）に宮内卿を辞職、同年のうちに薨去した。
sen.e: He resigned from Kunaikyo in 1730 and died in the same year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He resigned from Kunaikyo in 1730 and died in the same year.
He resigned from Kunaikyo in 1730 and died in the same year.
Died at 44.
Died at 44.
His age at death was 44.
